cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Evil Queen threatens Snow White, forcing her to flee into the forest.
As a cannibalistic witch whose house the siblings enter, she poses a threat to Hansel and Gretel.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: after they stumble upon her house
qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the house made of sweets
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implied by role, not directly mentioned

remarks: Relation added to capture implied antagonism; not explicitly stated in this short excerpt.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hansel outsmarts the witch in the Hansel and Gretel story.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the witch's dwelling in the Hansel and Gretel tale
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeOutcome: children escape and return home after outsmarting the witch

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Gretel outsmarts the witch in the Hansel and Gretel story.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the witch's dwelling in the Hansel and Gretel tale
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeOutcome: children escape and return home after outsmarting the witch

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject poses a danger or harmful intent toward the object, creating an antagonistic or threatening situation.
args.justification: Both relations describe an antagonist creating danger for a victim (Evil Queen toward Snow White; cannibalistic witch toward Hansel and Gretel). Normalizing to a single predicate 'poses_threat_to' captures this asymmetric threat relation consistently.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject defeats or overcomes the object primarily through superior cleverness, wit, or strategy in an adversarial context.
args.justification: Both instances describe a character (Hansel or Gretel) defeating the witch through cleverness in the same story context, so a shared predicate 'outsmarts' captures this adversarial, intellect-based victory.

All four relations occur between opposing characters in fairy tales and encode antagonistic or conflictual interactions (threatening or defeating an opponent), so they belong to a common adversarial interaction class.
These predicates describe how characters interact in the narrative (threatening, outsmarting) rather than composition, temporality, or identity, so they best fit a broad interaction-oriented group.

executed_decisions.justification: Both instances describe a character (Hansel or Gretel) defeating the witch through cleverness in the same story context, so a shared predicate 'outsmarts' captures this adversarial, intellect-based victory.

All four relations occur between opposing characters in fairy tales and encode antagonistic or conflictual interactions (threatening or defeating an opponent), so they belong to a common adversarial interaction class.
These predicates describe how characters interact in the narrative (threatening, outsmarting) rather than composition, temporality, or identity, so they best fit a broad interaction-oriented group.
